title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial experiment conducted by the speaker to demonstrate the concept of temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Measuring the temperature of a metal hard drive and a book

options.label: B
options.text: Measuring the temperature of an aluminium block and a plastic block

options.label: C
options.text: Measuring the temperature of a bath mat and a towel

options.label: D
options.text: Measuring the temperature of an ice cube on both blocks

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the initial experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The metal hard drive felt warmer than the book

options.label: B
options.text: The metal hard drive felt colder than the book

options.label: C
options.text: The metal hard drive and the book felt the same temperature

options.label: D
options.text: The metal hard drive and the book felt different temperatures

multiple-choice.question: What was the difference between the aluminium block and the plastic block in the second experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The aluminium block was a better conductor of heat

options.label: B
options.text: The plastic block was a better conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: The aluminium block and the plastic block were the same conductor of heat

options.label: D
options.text: The aluminium block and the plastic block were different conductors of heat

options.label: A
options.text: The ice cube melted faster on the plastic block

options.label: B
options.text: The ice cube melted faster on the aluminium block

options.label: C
options.text: The ice cube melted at the same rate on both blocks

options.label: D
options.text: The ice cube did not melt on either block

multiple-choice.question: Why did the aluminium block feel colder than the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the aluminium block was at a lower temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Because the aluminium block was a better conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: Because the plastic block was a better conductor of heat

options.label: D
options.text: Because the aluminium block and the plastic block were the same temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that explains why we feel certain temperatures when we touch different objects?
Why is it nicer to stand on a bath mat than on a towel beside it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from the body

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bath mat and the towel are the same temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between temperature and thermal conductivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Temperature is the rate at which heat is conducted, while thermal conductivity is the temperature of an object

options.label: B
options.text: Temperature is the temperature of an object, while thermal conductivity is the rate at which heat is conducted

options.label: C
options.text: Temperature is the rate at which heat is conducted, while thermal conductivity is the temperature of an object

options.label: D
options.text: Temperature and thermal conductivity are the same thing

title: What can Schr√∂dinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between classical mechanics and quantum mechanics?

options.label: C
options.text: Classical mechanics is a more complex theory than quantum mechanics.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum entanglement?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where two or more particles become connected in a way that their properties are correlated.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where two or more particles become disconnected in a way that their properties are not correlated.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where two or more particles become identical in a way that their properties are the same.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where two or more particles become different in a way that their properties are not the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the technical term for the state of two cats in boxes, where the outcome of the experiment is always one cat alive and the other cat dead?
How has quantum entanglement been confirmed in real-world lab experiments?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing the behavior of two particles that are entangled.

options.label: B
options.text: By measuring the properties of two particles that are entangled.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a system where the outcome of a measurement is always one cat alive and the other cat dead.

options.label: D
options.text: By showing that the states of cats on opposite sides of the universe can be entangled in a way that one cat lives or dies is completely undetermined before we measure the outcome.

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential applications of entanglement in quantum information science?
What is the study of quantum mechanics suggesting about the future of secure communication and computing?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will become more difficult to secure communication and computing.

options.label: B
options.text: That it will become easier to secure communication and computing.

options.label: C
options.text: That it will remain the same as it is now.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of wave-particle duality in quantum mechanics?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in multiple states simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in a state that is neither alive nor dead.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of a particle to exhibit both wave-like and particle-like behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in a state that is both alive and dead.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in multiple states simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in a state that is neither alive nor dead.

options.label: C
options.text: The inability to know certain properties of a particle at the same time.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of a particle to exist in a state that is both alive and dead.

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

multiple-choice.question: If a contestant chooses door number 1 on the game show "Let's Make a Deal," what is the probability that the car is behind door number 2?
If Monty Hall opens door number 2 on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the car is not behind that door, what is the probability that the car is behind door number 3?
If there are 100 doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the contestant chooses door number 1, what is the probability that the car is behind one of the other 99 doors?

If Monty Hall opens 98 of the other 99 doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the car is not behind any of those doors, what is the probability that the car is behind the remaining unopened door?
If a contestant sticks with their original choice on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" what is the probability of winning the car?
If a contestant switches doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" what is the probability of winning the car?
If there are 100 doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the contestant chooses door number 1, what is the probability that the car is behind door number 1?
If Monty Hall opens 98 of the other 99 doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the car is not behind any of those doors, what is the probability that the car is behind door number 1?
If a contestant sticks with their original choice on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the car is behind that door, what is the probability that the contestant will win the car?
If a contestant switches doors on the game show "Let's Make a Deal" and the car is behind the door they switched to, what is the probability that the contestant will win the car?

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate percentage of Europeans killed by the Black Death in four years?
What is the name of the bacterium that causes bubonic plague today and was also responsible for the Black Death?
How did the Black Death spread differently throughout history compared to modern instances of plague?

options.label: C
options.text: It was caused by different pathogens

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the population

multiple-choice.question: What led to explosive population growth throughout Europe during the High Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: A cooler climate and reduced agricultural production

options.label: B
options.text: A warmer climate and agricultural improvements

options.label: C
options.text: A decline in population and increased mortality rates

options.label: D
options.text: A lack of food and water resources

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the Black Death on Europe's economic conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decline in living standards and social mobility

options.label: B
options.text: It led to a rise in living standards and social mobility

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on economic conditions

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a decline in trade and commerce

multiple-choice.question: What was the biological impact of the Black Death on the human population?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decline in the human gene pool

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in the human gene pool

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the human gene pool

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the emergence of new diseases

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to learn more about the causes and effects of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how our world has been shaped by the past

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how to prevent future epidemics

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how to treat modern diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how to improve economic conditions

multiple-choice.question: What is the current threat level of the bubonic plague?

options.label: B
options.text: It continues to kill a few thousand people worldwide every year

options.label: C
options.text: It has been reduced to a minor public health issue

options.label: D
options.text: It has been replaced by a new disease

multiple-choice.question: What is the recent emergence of a drug-resistant strain of the bubonic plague a threat to?
What is the potential benefit of research into the genetic consequences of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to the development of new treatments for modern diseases

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the white intersections of the grid appear to flash grey in the peripheral vision?

options.label: B
options.text: The image is printed on a plain old piece of paper

options.label: C
options.text: Our retinal ganglion cells are organized to increase contrast with lateral inhibition

multiple-choice.question: What is the explanation for the muffin pan appearing to be defective?

options.label: B
options.text: The image is printed on a plain old piece of paper

options.label: C
options.text: Our brain's visual cortex operates on assumptions about the lighting of the image

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: C
options.text: To respond to edges and less to the crossings of lines

options.label: D

options.text: The image is printed on a plain old piece of paper

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: B
options.text: The image is printed on a plain old piece of paper

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: To create a tailored, edited vision of the world

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: C

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way in which coral reef fish larvae begin their life cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: By hatching from eggs that have been fertilized by parents

options.label: B
options.text: By drifting with the currents in the water column

options.label: C
options.text: By swimming to a suitable adult habitat

options.label: D
options.text: By absorbing oxygen directly from the water through their skin

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about coral reef fish larvae that has been disproven by recent research?

options.label: C
options.text: That they are able to navigate using sound and smell

options.label: D
options.text: That they are able to metamorphose into adults in one jump from the water column

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which coral reef fish larvae navigate to their adult habitats?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a complex suite of sensory systems, including sound and smell

options.label: B
options.text: By swimming to the nearest reef

options.label: D
options.text: By using a bungee system to check out the reef below

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a coral reef fish larva's bungee system?

options.label: A
options.text: To jump from the water column to a suitable adult habitat

options.label: B
options.text: To check out the reef below and then jump back up if conditions are not right

options.label: C
options.text: To navigate to the nearest reef

multiple-choice.question: What is still unknown about the life cycle of coral reef fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The geographic movements of individual larvae for most species

options.label: B
options.text: The exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to the reefs they will call home

options.label: C
options.text: The life cycle of coral reef fish

options.label: D
options.text: The number of coral reef fish species

multiple-choice.question: How do coral reef fish larvae typically obtain oxygen when they first emerge?

options.label: A
options.text: By swimming to the surface of the water

options.label: B
options.text: By absorbing oxygen directly from the water through their skin

options.label: C
options.text: By using a gill to extract oxygen from the water

options.label: D
options.text: By using a bungee system to check out the reef below

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of coral reef fish larvae using smell to navigate?

options.label: B
options.text: To distinguish between different environments, even adjacent reefs

options.label: C
options.text: To navigate to the nearest reef

multiple-choice.question: What is a common behavior of coral reef fish larvae when they find a suitable adult habitat?

options.label: A
options.text: They risk it all in one jump from the water column

options.label: B
options.text: They drop down in the water column to check out the reef below

options.label: C
options.text: They swim to the nearest reef

multiple-choice.question: What is still unknown about the life cycle of coral reef fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The life cycle of coral reef fish

options.label: B
options.text: The number of coral reef fish species

options.label: C
options.text: The geographic movements of individual larvae for most species

options.label: D
options.text: The exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to the reefs they will call home

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about coral reef fish larvae that has been disproven by recent research?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are able to navigate using sound and smell

options.label: C
options.text: That they are able to metamorphose into adults in one jump from the water column

options.label: D
options.text: That they are able to swim to a suitable adult habitat
